headline: No growth, toxic environment
pros:
The code base is easy to work with, readable and maintainable.
Almost no crunch/overtime.
cons:
For the Touch project:

Code reviews are used for hammer down anyone the reviewer doesn't like. If the reviewer wants to hurt your career, he just has to write 400 comments in your pull request and make it so that it takes 10x longer for you to deliver. 

Drive-by comments on reviews are common. Specially coming from the God developers that look down on the rest. God developers are a couple of developers that have been there since the beginning of the project and have gathered so much political clout that they might as well be the owners of the company. 

Everything is super hierarchical. They even have documents on confluence describing the development structure as an army; With soldiers at the bottom, lieutenants, generals, etc,

Career progression is almost non existent unless you play the political game. The usual progression is developer->functional analyst->manager.

The only opinion that matters is that of the God Developers. A lot of them are part of the Core Team. You will be just a cog in a very dumb machine.

No innovation going on at all. The work is brain-dead boring.

Leaving the project Touch, to do something else is considered some sort of promotion. That's sad.

headline: Overall a really poor company to work for
pros:
Very few. 
Staff on your level are mostly nice. Sports and social always run events.
cons:
No real respect shown from top to bottom. Staff have to log everything they do in a day into a system to an absolute tee. If there is a slight discretion your manager will pull you up on it. If you go to another persons desk for more than a minute you will be told to go and sit back down like a child. Senior management treat those below them extremely poorly, as if they are not even there. 

Reviews are done frequently, but for every positive, there is always a negative. If you worked well over the month they will pull you up either on productivity or QA score. QA score is done by two higher up employees who have the final say and more times than not your manager will side with them. 

Often times progress and treatment depends on how good mates you are with your manager. Managers will often give people they are mates with an easier run of things so it is not a level playing field.

On top of this the salary is a good bit below the industry average, bonuses are very poor as result. For the amount you have to put up with, the money simply isn't worth it.

I could go on and on but there is a character limit on this.

headline: Handling COVID
pros: I can not say one
cons:
The company gets people back to the office as quickly as possible disregarding all safety of employees.
We shall go into the big office, I should use public transport where I cannot keep social distancing, get into an over-crowded (yes, even with AB half people is overcrowded for COVID distance) open office with A/C on which is spreading the virus even further. Sit in small meetingrooms or touch the elevator and toilets after hundreds of people. All this for why? I worked effectively from home over the past weeks. This is all because it is an old bank and old habits never die, they cannot adapt. Seriously disappointed.

headline: Horrendous - HR hell!
pros: Absolutely none. I would not recommend working in the HR department.
cons:
Extremely poor management
Bullying culture 
Poor communication
Micro-management
Really poor HR knowledge within HR leadership team
Poor decision making e.g. decisions in HR are often made based on personal opinion and Company politics rather than whats best.
Style of management is to 'kick', not to lead 
HR staff often told 'if you are going to act like children, then we will treat you like children'
Oppressive environment 
No development opportunities (sneered at)
Certain senior HR people plagiarise other peoples work to ensure self preservation (and to secure their bonus). 
Performance management is non-existant. Staff are constantly marked down in yearly review and NEVER rewarded. 
Policies and procedures are not adhered to internally. 
Toxic environment and culture 
HR sick leave is really high.
HR staff turnover is high. People are scared to 'speak up' and when they do, they are bullied out. Others resign. 
Aggressive and passive aggressive behaviour towards staff

headline: Don't waste your time if you don't have a driver license or passport
pros:
They have silly stupid rules, it is mandatory to own a driver license or a passport you want to use their services(no matter what other official documents are you provide to them-Id Cards,official documents...etc)
I refused to believe till I had a phone discuttion with them. I've asked them: "Ok, what kind of document do you want to provide you if I don't have driver license or passport? Response: It's not possible without this"
I never saw such limitation to any international banking system till now(I was surprised).
cons: You need a driver license or passport to use their service

headline: Senior Portfolio Manager
pros: Excellent Experience gained through exposure to several aspects of the banking sector.  Good remuneration and benefits package available.  They offer broad job roles and have a positive working environment generally.  Regional presence in Cork also.
cons: There is a bit of uncertainty about where the long term future for the business lies.  It is rapdily growing its retail presence around the country and retrenching in former core business areas i.e. business lending and corporate banking.  Big management shake up in recent years with many "old" heads now retired or moved on.

headline: Backwards bank that bills itself as the way of the future but lacks the systems, want or ability to do so
pros: Salary and benefits. The  newer staff are fantastic  and very welcoming  and hard working
cons:
Don't be fooled by the great salary  and benefits.  You will pay for these via losing the will to live. 

I've  never  worked in a place that was so up its own behind. Nor have I ever  worked in a place  where both men and women  cried from stress on a daily basis. 

The hubs are a joke. You can't do anything in them apart from take the customers  request  and send it onwards  to HO. You must  also look like a model to get these roles while normal people  are employed  by HO.

KBC tries to portray itself as a company that is the future  for its staff and customers but fails by not having  the simple things like systems that work in place to enable  you to do your job.

Forget about climbing  the ladder  unless your old KBC staff.  The oldies obviously  know better than you and will shaft you  the first chance they get to get a pay rise, glory or a promotion.

They seem adamant  on hiring  people  who can't  read to work in their administration department  and this is where the biggest problem  the bank has comes from.  

This black hole affects  every area of the bank and results  in you getting torn  apart by customers as you try to explain  to them how some moron  who makes the same mistakes over and over, but still gets away with it as they are old KBC staff was only able to carry out part of their request  before  losing the page that had the rest of the instruction  on it.

The old KBC management  are ridiculous. They throw unrealistic  and unquantifiable  targets at you.  It's embarrassing  to see how these oldies  interact with the new arrivals  as they will go out  of their way to hold up progress. 

The stress levels are off the chart due to the daily  frustration you will endure due to the companies inability to implement  adequate  systems  that do the job.  

The customer  service team has it the worst. They are the front line and are the most abused as every  department  sends their mess that way.  It doesn't  help that it's managed  by a souless  machine and her self appointed lieutenants.

headline: Fast paced environemnt with a positive atmosphere
pros:
It has a good positive feel around the place with lots of new initiatives happening all the time.
There are only a small number of people working in KBC in Ireland, compared to other banks here, and so you get the opportunity to work on some of the new projects and gain alot of experience at the same time. 
Pay is ok, a bit higher than the previous bank I worked in, and benefits are ok
cons: The fast pace is a positive but sometimes it can become too much. There needs to be more recognition that people have worked really hard to get a successful launch and take the time to acknowledge this.

- you cannot stay here for a long time if you have any ambiotions
- after short time you dont have many new things to learn
- the most important thing for them is to lower the costs

cons: Salary is not bad, but still low compared to the same position at other companies. It seems that it pays off better to be an external worker rather than an internal employee as externs get paid better. Management is reacting slowly to market changes. Too many huge "transformation" programmes that remained unfinished.

headline: Good Place, bit protectionist
pros:
Working in the technology area gives you fantastic insights into organizing a huge enterprise application.
Most architectures are though old, very relevant and innovative.
The people are welcome to association even if you work from an overseas office.
Extraordinarily settled life and leisurely pace of life, (if you are working in projects driven by KBC and not as external consultant )
cons:
Extremely protectionist workforce, apparantly people are not welcome to aggressive change , ideas such as outsourcing, technology upgrade are viewed with suspicion and sometimes sabotaged.
Company is less responsible to its subsidiaries outside of Flanders even if wholly owned .
Controls are inadequate in some areas and long termers tend to become corrupt.

headline: KBC Bank and Insurance
pros:
a secure job , with a good private life work balance
a big company with good company bonuses
cons: low level professionalism of the management leading to a slow learning curve for the employees. Difficult environment for foreigners working within KBC. Not encouraging with regards to the initiatives.

headline: more cons than pros

cons: Evaluation criteria are absolutely of poor quality; almost no internal migration possibilities; unreachable management and intransparant internal communication.

headline: Worked here on an internship stint, overall was a neutral experience
pros: People are nice to you when you're young, willing to speak to you to help you learn more if you're interested
cons: Hierachy can be quite tall, many rooms for the various appointments create a power distance. Also, foreign branches may be quite small so promotions are limited

headline: Risk Management at KBC
pros: Risk management is a very challenging environment, intelectual growth opportunities arise for certain. Specifically quantitative profiles will enjoy this kind of job. KBC has great work-life balance.
cons: Office culture seems to be some years behind, very archaic, old structure; not so flexible etc. Older employees tend to live in a different era. Slow to recognize potential.

headline: Excellent, friendly and caring.
pros: Great people and working conditions.
cons: Head Office driven which restricts the scope of the people.

headline: Good for starting but not forever.
pros:
Job Security
Good Healthcare package
Good Work-Life balance
cons:
Easy going culture
Little accountability of management

headline: operation tranee
pros: easy people relationship, good benefit, work life balance
cons: slow growth, not much learning opportunity

headline: 9-to-life
pros: Good work life balance, intresting job opportunities. Lots of responsabilities are given, even to starters.
cons: Too much risk adverse. Too little reward (compensation for work).

headline: A bit too much of an administration feel
pros: Steady employer. OK wages for starters. Good if you want to be in a similar job for quite some time without being disturbed.
cons:
Quite a lot of B and C players (in contrast with so called A and A+ players in the metaphore used by e.g. Steve Jobs).
No real opportunities for people with vision or ambition. 
Slow moving. Bureaucratic. Political. "Dull".

headline: ICT Offshore Worker
pros:
-Well Structured and leisurely place to work
-Well established technologies and practices
-Reminds you of  stable, laid back, "utterly predictable" 50s style work life.
cons:
-Politics when it comes to outsourcing. 
-Employees of Offshore not counted as one with the mainstream.
-Too slow for agile competition.

headline: Fast yet thorough interview
pros: Great base salary and benefits. Solid employer.
cons: Long hours and complicated job substance

headline: Good experience
pros: Good internal courses, especially on financial services. Relatively few working hours. Some perks are still there even after the crisis.
cons: No self authority, unmotivating environment, not enough freedom is given for IT employees. Department interaction is very sluggish. Career advancement is slow.

headline: Good pay, no outlook, bad culture.
pros:
Fairly good money.
Fairly good environment to work in.
Good experience with financial institutions.
cons:
Bad company culture.
Unmotivated people.
Chaotic management, bad decision making.
No step forward for employees, no real career path.
Bad communication between departments.

headline: it is great place to work
pros: it is a casual atmosphere at work
cons: the company is not willing to pay

headline: Very good
pros: Flexibility, well-paid for students, few working hours
cons: Repetitive, little agency, not very diversified work

headline: Decent company
pros: Good trainings and process for emp
cons: Can embibe more professionalism culture

headline: In between the large corporate mentality and boutique flexibility
pros: niche player - CEE region
cons: affected by the financial crisis - lost some good personel
